Neighborhood Overview: El distrito Centro de Madrid es la zona más antigua ciudad. La primera constancia de la existencia de un asentamiento estable data de la época musulmana. En la segunda mitad de siglo ıx, el emir de Córdoba Muhammad ı (852-886) construye una fortaleza en un patrimonio junto al río, en el lugar que hoy ocupa el Palacio Real, con el propósito de vigilar los pasos de la Sierra de Guadarrama y ser punto de partida de razzias contra los reinos cristianos  del norte; actualmente aún se conservan algunos restos de la muralla. Junto a la fortaleza se desarrolla al este un pequeño arrabal. Esta población recibe el nombre de Mağrîţ o Magerit. A excepción de la muralla picos edificios se conservan de esta época.  La ciudad pasan a manos cristianas en 1085, prosperando hasta que en 1123 recibe el título de villa. Felipe ıı  decide instalar la corte en Madrid en 1561.Este echo será decisivo para la evolución de la ciudad.A partir de esta época se construye gran parte de los edificios y monumentos má

Neighborhood Overview: El Atelier Madrid se encuentra a 5 min de la Puerta del Sol, en una de las calles más ilustres de Madrid, La calle Mayor. Esta sigue conservando la importancia que ya tuvo durante la época medieval y que se agrandó al ser declarada Madrid capital de la Corte. Era la calle utilizada por los reyes para desplazarse desde el antiguo Alcázar (Palacio Real) hasta la Basílica de Atocha, los Jerónimos ó el Palacio del Buen Retiro.  El edificio fue construido en 1800 en la antigua ubicación de la iglesia de El Salvador, donde celebraban el Concejo de Madrid durante los siglos XIV y XV. En la zona se encuentran enclaves tan importantes como el Teatro Real, la catedral de la Almudena, el Barrio de los  Austrias entre otros y sitios turísticos como el mercado de San Miguel, indispensable para saborear los sabores típicos de la tierra y La Latina donde podrá disfrutar de las mejores tapas de Madrid y su famoso Rastro todos los domingos.
Street: Palacio, Madrid, Comunidad de Madrid 28013, Spain

Neighborhood Overview: Lavapiés junto con el barrio de La Latina (Austrias) es el barrio más antiguo de Madrid.  Madrid creció a partir del Palacio Real y sus primeros barrios poblados fueron estos. Fue barrio de convivencia de judíos, musulmanes y cristianos y sus estrechas calles y antiguas iglesias dan fe de ello. En la actualidad es un barrio joven, intercultural y plagado de bares típicos de tapeo y restaurantes con una variada oferta gastronómica. Dispones del único supermercado abierto 24 horas de Madrid en la misma Plaza de Lavapiés. Tienes multitud de bares para tomar cañas y cafés, así como pubs donde tomar la última copa y escuchar buena música. Es un barrio seguro donde la policía recorre con frecuencia sus calles para cualquier problema que puedas tener e incluso tiene un puesto fijo en la Plaza de Lavapies de Atención al Ciudadano. Neighborhood Overview: Huertas es también conocido como el “Barrio de las Letras”. Es dónde vivieron los escritores más importantes del Siglo de Oro de la literatura española.. Las calles que salen de Plaza de Santa Ana están pobladas de bares de tapas, restaurantes y de lugares para tomar una copa. Cada primer sábado de mes el mercadillo Frog’s Market tiene lugar en las calles del barrio, con vendedores de la zona (incluidos diseñadores, ropa vintage, antigüedades…)

Neighborhood Overview: Cortes is also known as the "Barrio de las Letras," or literary Madrid. This is where Spain's most celebrated Golden Age authors - Miguel de Cervantes, Lope de Vega, Calderón de la Barca, Tirso de Molina - lived in the 17th century. This is the best and nicest neighbourhood in central Madrid; you’ll immediately note how elegant it is from an architectural standpoint. The core of the “barrio” is Plaza de Santa Ana, and the streets radiating off this plaza are packed with bars -- good for tapas and experiencing the local life! On the first Saturday of the month, the “Frog Market” (Mercado de la Rana—named for the singing frogs that were in the area hundreds of years ago) takes place in the streets of Cortes; area retailers participate in this monthly market selling vintage clothes, furniture, and more. Neighborhood Overview: El barrio de Moscardó, perteneciente al distrito de Usera, en el sur de Madrid, linda, al noreste, con el río Manzanares; al sur, con el puente de Andalucía y la calle de Marcelo Usera; y, al noroeste, con el paseo de Santa María de la Cabeza. En el extremo norte, se ubica el puente de Praga y, en el extremo suroeste, la concurrida plaza Elíptica. El barrio es principalmente residencial y la mayor actividad comercial se da en la transitada calle de Marcelo Usera, en el borde sur.  Moscardó un barrio tranquilo, de clase media trabajadora, con sus comercios y establecimientos tradicionales, junto a nuevas actividades, con un porcentaje importante de inmigrantes que conviven en armonía con los vecinos de toda la vida y, efectivamente, han dado otros colores al barrio. La zona cuenta con equipamientos modernos y áreas verdes.

Neighborhood Overview: Lavapiés is considered to be Madrid’s coolest urban area! The heart of creativity in the capital paired with the colorful fusion of people and cultures produces Madrid's most interesting barrio!! On October 2014 "Lavapiés theater district" was created, a network of 15 independence theatre companies that offer more than 400 performances per year. Social diversity and vibrant Street Art is the visible flavor of the neighborhood. We recommend to visit the Tobacco Factory of Embajadores, a public ownership and under the Ministry of Culture through the General Directorate of Fine Arts (GDFA). This building has been listed as Heritage of Cultural Interest. There are dozens of ethnic bars, restaurants and cafes in which you can taste worldly flavors like Indian, Arabic, Bangladesh, Chinese, Japanese, Italian, Spanish, Vegan food...... These bars and coffee-shops have a friendly bohemian vibe which welcomes everyone who enters.  In the famous Argumosa street and Lavapiés street there are many

Neighborhood Overview: We live in the Malasaña neighbourhood within 3 and 5 minutes walking to Noviciado and Plaza de España underground station. Only 6 minutes walk from Gran Vía and 10 from Plaza de España you can head off to the Royal Palace which is 15 minutes away and wander around the district of Madrid de los Austrias, the Plaza Mayor (20 minutes) or the Rastro, a market which is held every Sunday selling old, new and antique articles.  On the other hand if it is shopping you want you can walk down Gran Vía to Plaza de Callao (6 minutes) away and to Puerta del Sol (10 minutes). Or you may want to visit the delightful areas of Malasaña and Chueca where not only will you will find shops selling the latest alternative fashion, design cafes but also the traditional shops and best night life in Madrid.

Neighborhood Overview: Callao is one of the most popular plazas in Madrid. It sits right on the edge of Madrid’s Theatre district, the very popular city centre Sol and beautiful Royal district of Opera. Plaza Callao is Madrids own version of Times Square with its tall buildings, busy streets and constant hustle and bustle. Not only is Callao great for it’s central location, it is a perfect spot for those interested in the theatre and cinema of Spain. All year round there are a wide variety of plays, musicals, movies and even special movie premiers. The neighborhood is a perfect mix between classic 1920’s and modern architecture – which makes it a great place to explore. And don’t forget about the shopping! The streets along Callao are some of the best in the city for clothing, shoes, makeup and technology. The flat is located in Calle Preciados and just 1 minute away from Plaza Callao. The area surrounding the building is a known spot for good restaurants and entertainment.

Neighborhood Overview: Madrid locals have many names for a long walk. At night, it’s called la marcha, a heady parade through a string of watering holes and nightclubs. At mealtime, it’s a tapeo, a long, grazing stroll through the city’s seething tapas bars. Among art lovers, it has another name: the Paseo del Prado. All cultural travel in Madrid begins with the Paseo del Prado. A broad boulevard just under a mile in length, it cuts a swath through the heart of the city, from the steel arcs of Atocha train station northward to the imposing Cybele Palace. Along the way, it hits the Golden Triangle of Art—three of the world’s top art museums in quick succession: the Prado, the Reina Sofía and the Thyssen-Bornemisza. At a brisk pace, the entire street is walkable in 20 minutes. But a proper exploration of all the cultural treasures along the Paseo, and in greater Madrid, would take years—not counting obligatory breaks for Rioja. So get walking, but don’t go too fast. This is Spain, after all. The Essentials Mus

Neighborhood Overview: La Latina es uno de los barrios más castizos de la ciudad de Madrid.  Se encuentra situado en el centro y sus calles, de origen medieval, giran en torno a las plazas de la Cebada y de la Paja. Las calles de este barrio reflejan el Madrid más popular. El lugar es muy frecuentado por los propios madrileños debido a sus numerosos bares, pubs y tabernas tradicionales llenas de encanto en calles como Cava Baja, Cava Alta o las mismas plazas de la Cebada y la Paja.  Aunque suele tener ambiente todo el tiempo, destacan los anocheceres y los fines de semana. Además, cada domingo, las calles de alrededor acogen el famoso Rastro de Madrid, un mercado popular al aire libre. Otro buen momento para visitar este barrio es durante la celebración de las fiestas de la Virgen de La Paloma. Tienen lugar en torno al 15 de agosto y son una de las celebraciones más castizas de Madrid. Neighborhood Overview: The neighborhood of La Latina is the oldest and most charismatic of Madrid. Its streets retain the layout already had for centuries, as seen in the plane of the Villa of 1656, and some of their names (door Moros, Plaza de la Cebada, street Morería, self-America) move us to a time when this area was the true center of life in the city. For locals this space formed between Calle Segovia, Vistillas, Puerta de Toledo, the Rastro and the Plaza de la Cebada not called otherwise than La Latina, and so is also reflected in the map of tourist areas published by the consistory itself. The name comes from Dona Beatriz Galindo, humanist and preceptor of the family of the Catholic Monarchs, who was known as America for being her teacher Latin, and whom the hospital foundation of America on the site should be where today find the Teatro La Latina.

Neighborhood Overview: I live in the famous neighborhood called Malasaña. A neighborhood that has evolved since the end of the dictatorship into a mature hip and very nice retro neighborhood. It belonged to one of the five central iconic neighborhoods of Madrid. Right next door is the quiet and beautiful square Guardia de Corps where the Conde Duque cultural center is situated. The huge complex was built in 1717 and served initially as the military headquarters of the city. In the neighborhood there are several restaurants with beautiful terraces, charming boutiques and the hippest coffee shops but you're also just a corner away of the city center with famous landmarks on your doorstep. Think of Plaza España with the statue of Don Quixote, The magnificent Royal Palace and Opera, Gran Via (the Broadway of Madrid) or Paque del Oeste with a real Egyptian temple and the best view of the sunset.

Neighborhood Overview: In the heart of the neighborhood is the Plaza de Dos de Mayo, where the former site of the Artillery Park of Monteleón was located, where the small French military force against the Napoleonic army, under the command Of two captains, Luis Daoíz and Pedro Velarde. In the remodeled square is preserved the arch of the old barracks, and under it a monument with sculptures of Antonio Solá. Other typical squares of the neighborhood are, for example, that of San Ildefonso and that of Santa María de Soledad Torres Acosta (better known as "Plaza Luna, Luna or Luna").Like many other central areas of Madrid, the neighborhood of Maravillas has quite an alternative atmosphere and nightlife. Some improvised chroniclers have come to compare it with the Camden Town of London, the East Village of New York, the Bairro Alto of Lisbon, the Baixa do Porto of Porto or the Kreuzberg in Berlin.

Neighborhood Overview: Located in the most centric location of the city is this elegant two-bedroom apartment, situated on the seventh floor. Set in the heart of Madrid, this apartment is just a short stroll to many of Madrid’s major highlights and attractions, including the two fantastic shopping streets of Fuencarral and Gran Via. In addition the apartment set in prime location for restaurants and historic sites, such as Puerta de Sol and Plaza Mayor, which are both found just round the corner. Meanwhile the small side streets sprouting from both Fuencarral and Gran Via are homes to charming bars, cafes, gourmet restaurants and boutique shops. The apartment itself is situated between two metro stations, therefore this home a hub for brilliant connections throughout the city. This makes it easier for our guests to explore beyond the buzzing city center.

Neighborhood Overview: LA LATINA The Latina area is an attractive part of old Madrid. In and around this area are the origins of Madrid. Apart from being one of the most attractive parts of the city to wander about in, it is home to many particularly fine tapas bars, restaurants, and many spots for nightlife and social life centered in the plazas de San Andres, de la Cebada and de la Paja. From San Francisco el Grande church, go up Carrera de San Francisco street. At the plaza de San Andrés, dominated by the dome of the Capilla de San Isidro, is the San Isidro Museum which shows the different of Madrid through the ages. The street Cava Baja nearby has excellent restaurants, among which the reknown Lucio, and fashionable bars. At the Plaza de la Cebada is the local covered market originally made of iron and glass, it was demolished in 1956 and rebuilt as we can see today. Neighborhood Overview: Located in Madrid ´s Soho, the neighborhood has seen an increase of its popularity in the last years and is currently one of the liveliest areas in the city center. Centrally located, most of the amenities are within walking distance; you can stop for a tapa in one of the countless bars or enjoy micro-theatre performances. You can wander in the little streets surrounding the historic Plaza del 2 de Mayo square which is just a stone throw from the Gran Vía Avenue and Plaza del Sol. The neighborhood counts as well on thriving cultural life such as theatres, art galleries and the main city museums (Prado, Reina Sofia, Thyssen), are very close. If you enjoy shopping, Fuencarral Street and its surroundings propose a vast array of trendy and vintage shops as well as the main international franchises.

Neighborhood Overview: Disfruta de una casa de diseño recién reformado por un arquitecto/interiorista en el corazón de Madrid. En la propia calle Mayor. Esta casa se encuentra en una ubicación inmejorable en pleno centro histórico. A un paso de todo lo que quieres ver en Madrid: La Puerta del Sol, Plaza Mayor, el Mercado de San Miguel, Teatro Real y Palacio Real. La zona es conocida como "Madrid de Los Austrias", con sus elegantes palacetes, plazas y pasadizos empedrados. En la Plaza Mayor se concentra la oferta cultural y de ocio: restaurantes internacionales, terrazas y tiendas de tendencias. No necesitarás ni transporte público, estás a un paso de la famosa La Latina, el Palacio Real, Ópera, Sol, y la Gran Vía. Las mejores tapas gourmet en Mercado de San Miguel, increíble edificio modernista renovado, justo en la esquina. En frente de la vivienda está la oficina central de información turística de Madrid.  A 5 minutos  (300m) de Gran vía centro neurálgico de las compras madrileñas. También del mítico Rast

Neighborhood Overview: The Retiro area is close to everything worthwhile in the city center. The Menendez Pelayo metro station is across the street (line 1). There is a supermarket across the street as well as the famous and historic Bodegas Casas-bar. There's a fruits and vegetable store around the corner, and Cafe del Comercio is good for coffee and breakfast. Neighbors, bar tender and vendors will all recognize you soon and will welcome you to the neighborhood. The Retiro park is at a 5 minutes walking distance, as well as the traditional Mercado Pacifico. More and more (trendy) bars and restaurants are opening up, there is a nice mix of traditional Spanish (non touristy) places and new and trendy places. We would recommend Bodegas Casas across the street and Bodegas Cuesta on Mendendez Pelayo. And also Fogg bar for artesan beers and the Greek restaurant on calle Juan de Urbieta.

Neighborhood Overview: La Latina is one of the most popular neighborhoods in Madrid; humble and somewhat neglected. Now it has an exotic, cosmopolitan flavor and it draws many visitors from other parts of Madrid, as well as foreign tourists. The architecture in La Latina, like other neighborhoods in Madrid is rather uniform with similar height, windows, balconies, light colours and shop/apartment set up. However, La Latina is unique in the sense that there are steep hills creating a dramatic effect on some streets as well as tall trees, something unique in the centre of Madrid. Located right in the city center, it's closed to most of the touristic attractions and cultural spots, such as Puerta del Sol, Plaza Mayor, Royal Palace and Cathedral, etc. There are plenty of restaurants, bars, terraces. Specially recommended Gau&Café terrace, where you can enjoy really good mojitos. Also, the most popular antique market in the city (El Rastro) is really closed to the apartment.
Street: La Latina, Madrid, Comunidad de Madrid 28005, Spain

Neighborhood Overview: El Apartamento San Ginés, se encuentra situado en el centro de Madrid,La ubicación es excelente en pleno barrio de los Austrias al lado de la plaza Mayor, Puerta del Sol y el Palacio Real, a distancia peatonal de museos, teatros, cines, restaurantes, bares de tapas y de los monumentos más emblemáticos. Perfectamente comunicado, con metro, tren de cercanias.. El llamado barrio de los Austrias es la zona donde se encuentran muchos lugares y monumentos construidos durante los siglos XVI y XVII, cuando la capital de España era la sede de la corte de los Austrias. Sus calles estrechas e irregulares, descubren edificios de arquitectura sobria y austera, acorde al carácter de aquellos monarcas. Pasear es la mejor forma de conocer esta parte de la ciudad, con sus numerosos comercios y tabernas tradicionales.

Neighborhood Overview: The apartment is located next to one of the the most important streets in Madrid, Calle Mayor, right in the center of the city. It's just a few meters away from Plaza Mayor (Major Square), where you'll find many restaurants and terraces to enjoy some tapas! If you are visiting on Christmas, you'll also see the famous Christmas Market. Thanks to its centric location, you can go by walk to most of the main places of Madrid, such as The Real Palace, Almudena's Cathedral, Sol Square, Gran Vía or Sabatini Gardens. Moreover, you are surrounded by many charming places. I recommend you to visit El Botin Restaurant, the oldest restaurant in the world, founded in 1725, and just 4 minutes away from the apartment. Another lovely place is the Sabatini Terrace, where you'll find really nice views of the Real Palace and the Sabatini Gardens (it's open just in summer). Neighborhood Overview: La Latina is one of the most genuinely authentic neighbourhoods in the city of Madrid. It is located in the centre, and its mediaeval streets are arranged around the squares of La Cebada and La Paja. The streets in this neighbourhood are an illustration of the most popular side of Madrid. This district is much frequented by Madrid locals thanks to its numerous bars, pubs and traditional taverns full of character in streets such as Cava Baja, Cava Alta and right in the squares of La Cebada and La Paja. Although it tends to be very lively all the time, the atmosphere is particularly animated in the evenings and at weekends. Additionally, every Sunday the neighbouring streets are home to Madrid's famous El Rastro open-air street market. Another good time to visit this neighbourhood is during the festivities in honour of the Virgin of La Paloma, which take place around 15 August and are some of the most authentic celebrations in Madrid. Neighborhood Overview: Se encuentra ubicado en el distrito de Hispanoamérica, barrio de Chamartín, zona de importantes escuelas de negocio a lo que acompañan lujosos restaurantes y comercios. Actualmente alberga la sede de varias de las empresas más importantes de España y contiene varias áreas de rascacielos, incluyendo las Torres Puerta de Europa, lindando con los edificios de AZCA y la CTBA. Entre sus puntos de interés se encuentran el Auditorio Nacional de Música, el Museo de Ciencias Naturales, el Museo de la Ciudad, el Parque del Canal de Isabel II y los Juzgados de la Plaza de Castilla. A escasos minutos del apartamento se encuentra el Parque de Berlín, perfecto para los paseos matutinos, un poco de running, disfrutar de sus zonas verdes o de sus pistas de fútbol y baloncesto. En sus proximidades se encuentra también el emblemático Estadio Santiago Bernabéu. Fácil acceso desde el aeropuerto. Es un barrio eminentemente residencial y comercial, que se encuentra muy bien comunicado. Perfecta localización

El barrio está lleno de sorpresas increíbles, buenos restaurantes y bares. Es sin duda un lugar muy original para conocer Madrid. La calle y el piso son muy silenciosos y los vecinos también. Properidad is one of the most authentic neighbourhoods in Madrid. You won´t find turists in here, but locals around. Is a very safe place and it´s full of surprises, from very good restaurants, to pubs. The flat is 2 min walking from Cartagena underground station, 5 min to Prosperidad and 7 minutes to Avenida de América. Neighborhood Overview: We are located in the very center of town. If you walk straight up our street, in about 7 minutes you will reach the Plaza Mayor. Walking 5 minutes in the opposite direction will take you to the San Franciso el Grande church with marvelous paintings, including by Goya. Royal Palace is about 9 minutes walk.  The Rastro, the largest flea market in Europe, in operation since the Middle Ages, starts two short block away from our door. It is operating every Sunday from 9 am to 3 pm, with some 3000 stalls where you can buy things new and old.  On weekdays, the same area is an antique hunter’s paradise. It is rather sleepy and half empty, but there are probably more than 100 antique stores within a very short walk. They open around 10 – 10:30 am. Go to Calle de la Ribera de Curtidores, which is parallel to our street. This is the main antiques street, there are shops every few meters and some courtyards with additional shops. Neighborhood Overview: Chueca is in the neighborhood of "Justicia", located in centre district of the city of Madrid, Spain. It is located in the heart of Madrid, next to Gran Via and Fuencarral streets and between Barquillo Street. In the 90s it became definitely gay neighborhood of Madrid, having been progressively chosen as place for recreation and residence of most of Madrid's gay community since the 80s. The neighborhood has a lively and modern character, very open and respectful of the diversity of modern society. It has a very commercial and recreational environment without losing its castizo air because of its architecture. In its streets, in addition to traditional stores, people may find restaurants, bars, fashion boutiques, etc. All this among its renovated buildings with colorful facades. This is a highly recommended neighborhood for walking while discovering its corners, and from where you the main sights of the city can be reached in a few minutes.

Neighborhood Overview: Junto a Gran Vía, STAR está localizado en el punto perfecto para iniciar la visita al Madrid monumental, gastronómico, cultural y nocturno. Quieres descubrirlo?  - VISITA MONUMENTAL: LA CASA DE LUNA es un excelente punto de partida para visitar el Madrid de los Austrias, la plaza Mayor, la zona de Opera con el Palacio de Oriente, El Retiro... - MUSEOS: Bajando hacia Cibeles por la Gran Vía llegamos al Paseo del Prado, con la mejor oferta de Museos de la Ciudad: Museo Thysen, El Prado, Reina Sofía y CaixaForum son los principales. - QUE HACER: STAR está en pleno "soho" madrileño, un barrio con una intensa vida cultural. Neighborhood Overview: Located in the historical center it represents a great choice for anyone looking to spend time in the exciting and vibrant Spanish capital. This area includes the origins of Madrid through its narrow winding streets. It located in the heart of old Madrid, the area of greatest personality of the city and best commercial, cultural and leisure activities. You only have to go a little beyond Plaza Mayor to discover some of the great surprises Madrid offers, as the Mercado de San Miguel, a beautiful iron structure dating from 1913 and which houses an interesting Spanish cuisine where you can taste and buy high quality products. A few steps away is the “Arco de Cuchilleros”, a good place to drink good wine in his classic taverns or eat in typical Castillian mesons. The best known is La Casa Botin, founded in 1725, it still retains the old house and the original oven. Also a few minutes away you will find the Almudena Cathedral and the Royal Palace, the elegant Plaza de Oriente and the Opera

Neighborhood Overview: La calle Ventura de la Vega es conocida como la "calle del sabor" por los numerosos buenos restaurantes que aquí se encuentran. El barrio de las Letras es conocido por ser el lugar donde vivieron y coincidieron en el tiempo grandes literatos de los siglos XVI y XVII, los siglos de oro de la literatura castellana. El apartamento está situado en la calle Ventura de la Vega, calle que recibe su nombre en honor al escritor Buenaventura José María de la Vega y Cárdenas, escritor de principios del siglo XIX más conocido como Ventura de la Vega. Muy cerca de casa se encuentra la calle donde nació Lope de Vega, gran dramaturgo, buscavidas, aventurero, genio de la literatura y sacerdote español. En esa misma calle, Lope de Vega, y unos metros más abajo se encuentra el convento de las Trinitarias Descalzas de San Ildefonso. En este convento fue enterrado Miguel de Cervantes en 1616. Es interesante pues se ofician misas diarias que dan la oportunidad de visitar el convento. Cervantes nació a esca

Neighborhood Overview: Malasaña is an area of Madrid famous for its trendy alternative scene. Centred around Plaza Dos de Mayo, it is reminiscent of Camden Town in London, the East Village in New York City, or Bairro Alto in Lisbon, although the layout is quite different and the emphasis is less on shops and more on bars. Malasaña is to the west of Chueca and to the east of Argüelles. It was the centre of the movida movement in late 1970´s and 1980´s Madrid. Malasaña is a vibrant neighborhood full of lively bars and restaurants overflowing with young people. Its streets are currently being renovated, making it a much more attractive quarter (the streetworks are almost finished). It's one of the classic areas for partying the night away. The area's center is the Plaza del Dos de Mayo (in commemoration of a popular uprising on May 2, 1808, brutally repressed by the French troops and which started the Spanish Independence War). Although popularly known as barrio Malasaña, it is known by residents as Maravillas

Neighborhood Overview: El apartamento está ubicado en un barrio mítico de Madrid, Chamberí. Existen numerosos autobuses y varias bocas de metro andando como mucho 10 minutos desde casa (Islas Filipinas, Canal, Moncloa, Quevedo, Argüelles). The neighborhood has been rejuvenated recently; it has become more cosmopolitan, which is seen in the diversity of its shops, galleries, bars, bookstores, restaurants and new cultural proposals. Neighborhood Overview: La Latina is one of the most genuinely authentic neighbourhoods in the city of Madrid. It is located in the centre, and its mediaeval streets are arranged around the squares of La Cebada and La Paja. The streets in this neighbourhood are an illustration of the most popular side of Madrid. This district is much frequented by Madrid locals thanks to its numerous bars, pubs and traditional taverns full of character in streets such as Cava Baja, Cava Alta and right in the squares of La Cebada and La Paja. Although it tends to be very lively all the time, the atmosphere is particularly animated in the evenings and at weekends. Additionally, every Sunday the neighbouring streets are home to Madrid's famous El Rastro open-air street market. Another good time to visit this neighbourhood is during the festivities in honour of the Virgin of La Paloma, which take place around 15 August and are some of the most authentic celebrations in Madrid. Neighborhood Overview: The flat is perfectly located in a sunny and quiet street between LAVAPIÉS, the most bohemian area of Madrid with a popular atmosphere and LA LATINA, the Rastro market area.  It's a friendly multicultural neighborhood, where you can find sunny terraces to taste authentic Spanish cuisine but also an international offer and cool hangouts. Plus, you will be at a short walk from the Museum area of Madrid: Reina Sofia, Prado, Thyssen and Caixa Forum.  It is a great place to start your exploration of the city! The street where the flat is located will lead you directly to the Rastro vintage market every Sunday, a must-see in town.  Just around the corner you can also discover the very local and yet unknown covered food market of San Fernando which offers an amazing atmosphere every week-ends with live music and tapas bars, and plenty of fresh food shops during the weeks. Neighborhood Overview: Close to the city center by public transport, but cheaper to live than Madrid's downtown. It has the traditional atmosphere of neighbourhoods in Madrid, but with multicultural residents due to inmigration in the last 15 years. Less than 100 meters from the apartment there are restaurants (Chinese, Peruvian, Ecuatorian, Moroccan, Spanish) with affordable meals ('menu del día') and quality food, as well as one of the best breweries on tap in Madrid (El Boliche) and a homy bar where you can sample exotic meat (gnu, zebu, kobe and so on). There are also pastry shops (Spanish and Latin American ones), a chocolate stand, two supermarkets, one traditional market, pharmacies, and a boulevard full of terraces.  In the nearby Albufera Avenue there are numerous banks and all kinds of trade. Neighborhood Overview: La Latina is one of the most genuinely authentic neighbourhoods in the city of Madrid. It is located in the centre, and its mediaeval streets are arranged around the squares of La Cebada and La Paja. The streets in this neighbourhood are an illustration of the most popular side of Madrid. This district is much frequented by locals thanks to its numerous bars, pubs and traditional taverns full of character in streets such as Cava Baja, Cava Alta and right in the squares of La Cebada and La Paja. Additionally, every Sunday the neighbouring streets are home to Madrid's famous El Rastro open-air street market. This neighbourhood today is on the site of what was Madrid's first urban walled enclosure in the Middle Ages, and even now some remains of the defensive wall which originally surrounded it can still be seen. In the past this area was mainly occupied by artisans and manual workers, and the squares of both the Plaza de la Cebada ('barley square') and the Plaza de la Paja ('straw square

Neighborhood Overview: The district of the Letters, also called of the Literates or district of the Muses is an area bounded, towards the west, by the calle de la Cruz and the place of Jacinto Benavente; To the east, by the Paseo del Prado; To the north, by the Carrera de San Jerónimo;  And, to the south, by the calle de Atocha. Some of its most emblematic streets and squares are the Plaza de Santa Ana, Calle de las Huertas, Plaza del Angel, Paseo del Prado and calle de Echegaray, among others It owes its name to the literary activity developed throughout the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. In this area some of the most outstanding writers of the Spanish Golden Age, such as Miguel de Cervantes, Quevedo, Góngora (who lived in the same house as his literary antagonist,  Quevedo), or Lope de Vega and his idolized Marta de Nevares. With such protagonists  and in this frame the first corrals of comedies of Madrid were installed, two of them, the one in Calle de la Cruz and other  one in Calle del Principe, i

Neighborhood Overview: Callao is one of the most popular plazas in Madrid. It sits right on the edge of Madrid’s Theatre district, the very popular city centre Sol and beautiful Royal district of Opera. Plaza Callao is Madrids own version of Times Square with its tall buildings, busy streets and constant hustle and bustle. Not only is Callao great for it’s central location, it is a perfect spot for those interested in the theatre and cinema of Spain. All year round there are a wide variety of plays, musicals, movies and even special movie premiers. The neighborhood is a perfect mix between classic 1920’s and modern architecture – which makes it a great place to explore. And don’t forget about the shopping! The streets along Callao are some of the best in the city for clothing, shoes, makeup and technology. The flat is located in Calle Preciados and just 1 minute away from Plaza Callao. The area surrounding the building is a known spot for good restaurants and entertainment.

Neighborhood Overview: The " Barrio de las Letras " is one of the most historic neighborhoods of Madrid.The triangle formed by Puerta del Sol , Atocha and the Fountain of Neptune is a semi- pedestrianized area, which makes this area an oasis of tranquility and safety in the heart of Madrid. In it you will find a variety of shops and art galleries, cozy cafes , local live music and the best hotels in Madrid: The Westin Palace , Urban, Villa Real and Palacio de Tepa - all 5 star hotels. The name " Barrio de las Letras " , comes from the XVI and XVII century. This neighborhood was home to the most outstanding writers of the Spanish " Golden Age ". Cervantes, Quevedo , Gongora and Lope de Vega were some of the most illustrious residents. We can now stroll through the streets named after these writers and even stumble upon the ground that brought up these ancient inhabitants. Neighborhood Overview: To let yourself into the Barrio de las Letras is to plunge into the living history of the Spanish Golden Age. The framework of the neighborhood suggests, with every step we take, the prose and verse of Calderón, Lope de Vega, Quevedo and so many men and women that with their lived and written word have made this historical place so grand. The Barrio de las Letras boasts first class neighbors living in its surroundings: The Prado Museum, The Thyssen Museum, The Reina Sofía Arts Centre, and within its limits, the Medialab and the Caixa Forum. This artistic spirit makes the neighborhood a very special place to be, and also marks it as the place with the best Madrid has to offer: the so-called Art strip, that leads to the Madrid de los Austrias-Plaza Mayor-Puerta del Sol, and it is also very close to the Alcalá-Gran Vía zone, as well as Paseo de la Castellana, Colón and Serrano. Neighborhood Overview: El encanto del Madrid antiguo se encuentra en lo que los madrileños llaman "El Madrid de los Austrias". Este sobrenombre de esta parte del distrito centro madrileño tiene origen histórico: es en esta zona donde la dinastía de los Habsburgo creo los edificios históricos de una villa que ellos eligieron como capital de España. Sus edificios recuerdan la época imperial española, cuando los Habsburgo regentaban un imperio que iba desde más allá de los Paises Bajos hasta América. Los Austrias se extiende desde Sol recorriendo Mayor y Arenal hasta La Latina y la Plaza de Oriente. La manera de empezar el recorrido es andar los escasos metros que separan la Puerta del Sol de la Plaza Mayor. Esta Plaza es el corazón de los Austrias y tiene a un lado la Calle Mayor que lleva a Bailén y la Almudena - Plaza de Oriente - Palacio Real. Neighborhood Overview: Huertas is also known as the "Barrio de las Letras". It is where lived the most important writers of the golden age of Spanish literature in the 17TH century: Cervantes, Lope de Vega and Tirso de Molina, Calderón de la Barca. Cortes was his inspiration, writing and representation of their works. You will immediately notice the architectural elegance of the neighbourhood in a ride that transports us to another time. The streets which depart from Plaza de Santa Ana are populated with tapas bars, restaurants and places for a drink. Every first Saturday of the month the Frog completo Market flea market takes place in the streets of the neighborhood, with sellers in the area (including designers, vintage, antique clothing...)

Neighborhood Overview: Madrid ofrece innumerables lugares para visitar y rincones para perderse. Te presentamos las visitas imprescindibles en Madrid: Nuestras cinco visitas clave Puerta del Sol La Puerta del Sol es una de las plazas más conocidas de Madrid. En ella encontraréis puntos de interés tan interesantes como El Oso y el Madroño y el Kilómetro Cero. Plaza Mayor A pocos metros de la Puerta del Sol y el Palacio Real encontramos la Plaza Mayor de Madrid, una de las más antiguas de España construida por Juan de Herrera y Juan Gómez de Mora en los siglos XVI y XVII. Gran Vía La Gran Vía es la calle más famosa de Madrid, en ella encontraremos los cines y teatros más importantes de la ciudad. Una calle que nunca duerme. El Retiro El Retiro es el parque más conocido de Madrid desde su apertura al público en el siglo XIX. Un lugar imprescindible para ir con los niños. Neighborhood Overview: The Barrio de las Letras is a central neighborhood of the city of Madrid in which some of the great literary men of Spain have lived and written. Today is an area that combines literature, bohemia, fun, shopping and fine cuisine. The neighborhood is formed by small streets, pedestrian or restricted access to vehicles, and pleasant squares such as Santa Ana. In them, it is easy to find houses in which they lived and wrote such important figures of the literature of the Golden Age of Spain Like Lope de Vega, Quevedo, Góngora or Cervantes. Also, on the pavement of various streets are inscriptions and small texts of the work of some of them. Another of the charms of the "Barrio de las Letras" is its wide range of shops, ranging from the most traditional establishments with centuries of history (such as cobblers, silversmiths or lutieres) to modern and avant-garde spaces. Neighborhood Overview: With a fantastic location right in the heart of el barrio de los Austrias in the centre of Madrid, the area surrounding the property boasts wonderful views of the city. Just by walking a few minutes from the apartment guests can watch the sun set over La Almudena cathedral and the beautiful Casa de Campo park, the capital’s largest green space, perfect for walking, cycling or picnicking. The area surrounding the apartment is one of the oldest and most typical of Madrid, with historical buildings at every turn and traditional shops, tabernas and cafes on every corner. The neighbouringbarrio of La Latina is the place to go for some of the best tapas, food and socializing in the city, while many of Madrid’s top cultural sights and attractions are within easy walking distance. These include the Royal Palace, the bustling Plaza del Sol and the lovely Campo del Moro, a quiet garden oasis tucked behind the Palace and filled with exotic birds.

Neighborhood Overview: The flat is very close to two very different parts of the city. By one side you can find Lavapiés, an old neighborhood of Madrid with a vivid ambience, art galleries and a mix of people from different countries and cultures. By the other side you can find the area of the museums, one of the most exclusive areas of Madrid. The Museo Reina Sofía, with works of Picasso, Dalí, Miró, etc. is at 100 meters of the house, the Prado Museum is also very close and also Thyssen Museum. At 4 minutes walking is the Botanic Garden and at 7 minutes walking is the Retiro park. This is the biggest park of Madrid, with 4 centuries of history, 118 hectares of trees, interesting buildings to see and also a lake.

Neighborhood Overview: La Latina es uno de los barrios más castizos de la ciudad de Madrid. Se encuentra situado en el centro y sus calles, de origen medieval, giran en torno a las plazas de la Cebada y de la Paja. Las calles de este barrio reflejan el Madrid más popular. El lugar es muy frecuentado por los propios madrileños debido a sus numerosos bares, pubs y tabernas tradicionales llenas de encanto en calles como Cava Baja, Cava Alta o las mismas plazas de la Cebada y la Paja. Aunque suele tener ambiente todo el tiempo, destacan los anocheceres y los fines de semana. Además, cada domingo, las calles de alrededor acogen el famoso Rastro de Madrid, un mercado popular al aire libre. Otro buen momento para visitar este barrio es durante la celebración de las fiestas de la Virgen de La Paloma. Tienen lugar en torno al 15 de agosto y son una de las celebraciones más castizas de Madrid. Durante las mismas, las calles se llenan de fiesta, se organiza una popular verbena y muchos madrileños se visten con sus traj

Neighborhood Overview: En los márgenes occidentales de Madrid y que desciende hacia el río Manzanares se encuentra el Parque del Oeste (Western Park). Esta zona también se llama Rosales. Es un hermoso antiguo jardín de 98 hectáreas con amplias extensiones de césped y árboles viejos de sombra. Hay un gran jardín de rosas por la colina, "La Rosaleda", diseñado en 1900 por el paisajista Cecilio Rodríguez. Un espectáculo rosa se celebra allí cada primavera, y premios internacionales se dan a las mejores flores. El parque fue creado en 1906 cuando el actual alcalde de Madrid don Alberto Aguilera, decidió crear un paseo para los madrileños. El parque está situado en una ladera, diseñado en un estilo Inglés, tiene cedros, abetos, hayas, pinos ... y caminos serpenteantes a la sombra. En el parque también se encuentran algunas instalaciones interesantes: la estación del teleférico que lleva a la Casa de Campo, la Escuela de Cerámica, el parque Tinaja y un quiosco de música Music. Templo de Debod madridTemplo de Debod

Neighborhood Overview: El barrio de Salamanca, es uno de los mejores barrios de Madrid. La tranquilidad y la arquitectura de sus casas y calles, posibilitan al barrio albergar los mejores comercios y los mejores restaurantes.  El piso se encuentra en una situación privilegiada y tranquila, con fácil acceso y bien comunicado. Muy próximo al Parque del Retiro y a pocos minutos andando de los museos del Prado, museo arqueológico, Thyssen, Jardín Botánico, de la puerta del Sol, Plaza Mayor, etc… Al igual que el Central Park en New York, el Parque del Retiro es el pulmón de Madrid, donde los madrileños y turistas acuden a desconectar, practicar deporte, tomar el sol, hacer picnic. Por lo que el alojamiento está situado en una de las zonas de aire más limpias de la capital.

Neighborhood Overview: PLAZA DE SANTA ANA This buzzing square is a popular start for many a Madrileño's Friday night chateo (tapas crawl). It is flanked at either end by the elegant 18th-century Teatro Español (Spanish Theatre) and the famous Gran Hotel Reina Victoria that's recently morphed into the ME Madrid Reina Victoria. Once favoured by bullfighters, the Reina is now a serious contender for the late-shift party crowd at its rooftop and lobby bars.  It's worth a quick ice-cold beer at two of Hemingway's favourite bars close by; Viva Madrid (in Manuel Fernández y González street) is famous for its walls decorated with hand-painted tiles depicting turn-of-the-century scenes, and still lives off its reputation for attracting the likes of Ava Gardner and bullfighter Manolete, who made out at one of its intimate tables. Hemingway's other favourite, Cervecería Alemana, is a wood-panelled gem with decent plates of jamón, white asparagus and fried squid. Try nearby Casa Alberto before wandering down popular Cal

Neighborhood Overview: This apartment is right in the centre of Madrid, between the neighbourhoods of Los Austrias and La Latina, in the oldest and loveliest part of the city. It has an unbeatable location in Plaza de Cascorro off Calle Duque de Alba, a few metres from Mercado de la Cebada, Calle Toledo and Plaza Mayor. El Rastro, a traditional open-air market, is held on Sundays in the area around the apartment, when the streets are closed to traffic until midday. La Latina is a must-see neighbourhood in Madrid. It is one of the most authentic places in the city, with lots of bars, tapas restaurants and sites of artistic interest. Strolling along its narrow streets is a delight. It is within easy walking distance of Museo del Prado, Museo Thyssen and Jardín Botánico.

Traditional architecture – old churches and taverns from yesteryear – have become amalgamated with present-day, avant-guarde fashion boutiques, as well as contemporary restaurants, bars and cafes. The apartment enjoys quite an idyllic urban situation. Many the city's key places of interest lie within easy reach, like the ever-dynamic Calle Fuencarral (Fuencarral St.) – full of shops and top brands. At the tail end of Fuencarral is the majestic Gran Vía, with its imposing buildings. And, from there, a short walk takes you to the famous Puerta del Sol ('Gateway to the Sun'). Neighborhood Overview: Callao is one of the most popular plazas in Madrid. It sits right on the edge of Madrid’s Theatre district, the very popular city centre Sol and beautiful Royal district of Opera. Plaza Callao is Madrids own version of Times Square with its tall buildings, busy streets and constant hustle and bustle. Not only is Callao great for it’s central location, it is a perfect spot for those interested in the theatre and cinema of Spain. All year round there are a wide variety of plays, musicals, movies and even special movie premiers. The neighborhood is a perfect mix between classic 1920’s and modern architecture – which makes it a great place to explore. And don’t forget about the shopping! The streets along Callao are some of the best in the city for clothing, shoes, makeup and technology. The flat is located in Calle Preciados and just 1 minute away from Plaza Callao. The area surrounding the building is a known spot for good restaurants and entertainment.

Neighborhood Overview: The apartment: With three separate bedrooms and a living room, the Museo Reina Sofía apartment can sleep eight.  The main bedroom has an ensuite bathroom with shower, a large walk-in wardrobe and windows onto an inner courtyard. The second, well-lit bedroom has two single beds and windows that overlook the plaza. The third, good-sized bedroom has a truckle bed and windows that overlook the plaza. The second and third bedrooms are south facing and get lots of sunlight during the day. The living-dining room has an L-shaped double sofa bed for the 6th and 7th guests. The apartment has been decorated in great style with careful attention paid to every last detail. The cutting-edge colours and furniture lend the rooms a modern air. The living room has a balcony with two chairs for taking in the view and enjoying the sun. The second bathroom, off the corridor, has a shower. The modern kitchen is fully equipped with all the utensils you’ll need. The apartment has Internet and air conditioning

Neighborhood Overview: En el Barrio de las Letras se oferta una completa gama de comercios, que van desde los más tradicionales, con siglos de historia, a los más modernos que responden a las últimas tendencias. Tradición y vanguardia se funden; el mundo de lo permanente y de lo efímero se dan la mano para ofrecer el mejor abanico de posibilidades a todos los visitantes.   Comprar en el Barrio de las Letras se convierte en un verdadero deleite dada su amplísima y rica variedad de comercios, donde la calidad es el común denominador, así como el cuidado trato de sus comerciantes. Las galerías de arte, las platerías y anticuarios, las librerías, las tiendas de moda, de música, de decoración... ofrecen el mejor servicio a los clientes más exigentes.  De cualquier parte del mundo llegan personas para adquirir objetos de coleccionista o de última moda en las tiendas del Barrio. Neighborhood Overview: Barrio tradicional A pesar de que en los últimos años se ha convertido en uno de los barrios más populares (y caros) para vivir, La Latina forma parte del Madrid más antiguo y tradicional. Buena muestra de ello son sus restos de murallas, las grandes y pequeñas iglesias distribuidas aparentemente al azar por sus calles e incluso el viaducto de Segovia y la Puerta de Toledo, que marcan los límites el barrio. El Mercado de la Cebada, uno de los más grandes de Madrid, aúna a la perfección esa fusión entre lo tradicional y lo moderno que caracteriza esta zona. De tapas y copas La Latina es sinónimo de salir de cañas en Madrid. Los fines de semana es prácticamente imposible encontrar hueco en la barra de un bar o una mesa libre en alguno de sus muchos restaurantes. Las dos principales calles donde se localizan la mayoría de los locales son la Cava Alta y la Cava Baja, ubicación del mítico Casa Lucio, famoso por su plato de huevos estrellados. Neighborhood Overview: Lavapiés is an informal neighbourhood of the city. The name literally means "wash feet" possibly in the fountain in Plaza de Lavapiés which no longer exists. The architecture of Lavapiés  is rather uniform with similar height, windows, balconies, pastel colours, but deeply personal. The atmosphere of the nightlife of Lavapiés can be divided into three parts: South of the Plaza are several bars and cafes with a bohemian vibe and many terraces; Calle Ave María and East of it, are many alternative bars not to mention fringe meetings (parties or artistic/musical meetings) also happen in abandoned or places. There are also several shisha bars and the Melos, a bar selling his renowned Zapatilla, (a 1K sandwich made with ham and cheese).

It is one of the safest and most sought-after districts in the centre of Madrid, within easy reach of the main sights. It is both a residential and a lively commercial area. Neighborhood Overview: The apartment is located in the historic center of Madrid, with views of the whole city and fast connections to everywhere, whether on foot or by public transport. The apartment is fantasically located, with the metro just steps away. The location isn't in a overly touristy area, at the same time the apartment is walking distance from all the major sights.  La Latina occupies much of the oldest section of Madrid, sometimes referred to as Madrid de los Austrias which maintains a peculiar urban layout similar to the medieval distribution, with spacious squares and narrow streets that follow the former course of creeks.  Its streets have felt the presence of all historical events that took place in Madrid in all periods, without losing its popular character. In this sense it can be said that La Latina constitutes a large part of the true historic center of Madrid.

Neighborhood Overview: Malasaña is one of the trendiest "barrios" in Madrid, you can stop for a tapa in one of the countless bars or enjoy micro-theatre performances. You can wander in the little streets surrounding the historic Plaza del 2 de Mayo square just a stone throw from the Gran Vía Avenue and Plaza del Sol. The neighborhood counts as well on thriving cultural life such as theatres, art galleries and the main city museums (Prado, Reina Sofia, Thyssen), which are very close. Fashion victims will be pleased to stroll through Fuencarral Street and its surroundings with their vast array of trendy and vintage shops as well as the main international franchises. Es bastante tranquilo, aunque está rodeado de restaurantes, cafeterías, bares, tiendas y bancos. The district, over 500 years of history, was the old Jewish quarter of the city. An event that marked forever the future of the neighborhood. With the expulsion of the Jewish community, the synagogue was demolished and on the same site the Church of San Lorenzo rose. In an attempt to erase all traces of the past, names were put to new streets were a declaration of intent, with strong religious character. Calle de la Fe, or the Calle del Ave Maria is one example. Of that medieval times, the neighborhood inherited a trait that would follow him throughout history and nobody could erase his name. Neighborhood Overview: La zona comprendida entre la Puerta del Sol y la Gran Vía y sus alrededores es, sin duda, el eje sobre el que gira la vida turística, cultural y lúdica madrileña. Esta área suele ser punto de partida o rúbrica de cualquier ruta turística por la ciudad, y en su defecto, es punto de paso obligado para cualquier visitante que quiera sentir los latidos del corazón de Madrid. La Puerta del Sol fue en siglo XV la que situaba los límites orientales de la ciudad. Tras su expansión hacia el este fue convirtiéndose en el centro neurálgico de la vida madrileña. Es punto de encuentro para visitantes y madrileños que concretan sus citas ya sea en el Kilómetro 0, en la estatua del oso y el madroño, en la estatua ecuestre de Carlos III o en la reproducción de la Mariblanca. Cada 31 de diciembre se reúnen aquí miles de personas para saludar al nuevo año al son de las doce campanadas de su reloj. Neighborhood Overview: El Barrio de Salamanca de Madrid es famoso por su exclusividad, ya que se trata de una de las zonas más elegantes y de mayor precio de la ciudad. En este sentido, es un verdadero privilegio poder aprovechar las oportunidades que ofrece, tanto por su céntrica ubicación como por sus atractivos: la calle Serrano es la zona por excelencia de las compras de lujo, y en la calle Goya podemos encontrar tiendas más asequibles. Por otra parte, no sólo se puede llegar caminando a algunos de los lugares más emblemáticos de Madrid, como la Puerta de Alcalá, el Retiro, la Plaza de Colón, la Gran Vía o el Triángulo de los Museos, sino que este apartamento ofrece también un centro neurálgico inigualable para experimentar la vida nocturna de la ciudad: discotecas como Green o Serrano 41, bares como Serrano 100, o restaurantes como el famoso Ten Con Ten se encuentran a tan solo un par de manzanas. Neighborhood Overview: Es una calle muy tranquila y silenciosa, en un barrio céntrico y monumental. En su extremo oeste están ubicados el Palacio Real y sus jardines contiguos (el Parque Campo del Moro y los Jardines de Sabatini). Al norte, linda con la plaza de España y la calle Gran Vía; al este, con la calle de Toledo y otras calles próximas a la plaza de la Puerta del Sol; y, al sur, con la ronda de Segovia. Es una de las zonas más agradables de Madrid para pasear, especialmente el conjunto peatonal compuesto por el Palacio Real y sus jardines, la catedral de Santa María la Real Almudena, el Teatro Real y la plaza de Oriente, en la cual hay distinguidas cafeterías que ponen terrazas. La calle Mayor, la calle del Arenal y la calle Bailén son especialmente interesantes y cuentan con múltiples tiendas, bares y restaurantes. La zona está bien comunicada mediante autobuses y metro (La Latina, Ópera, Santo Domingo y Gran Vía).

Neighborhood Overview: Barrio Lavapies, su nombre proviene de la antiguedad, donde en su plaza existia una gran fuente de agua, por ser antiguo barrio judio esta fuente insitaba a que los musulmanes  debian lavarse los pies antes de entrar al templo.  Hoy dia es un barrio con gran poblacion de extranjeros y debido a esta multiculturalidad, eventos como el año nuevo chino y el ramadan son de mucha resonancia. Sin embargo, la popular verbena de las fiestas de San Lorenzo es el evento mas celebrado en el barrio lavapies. El barrio cuenta con un sin fin de bares y restaurantes donde predomina el curry y las especias de la cocina Hindú. Y Si te gustan los mercadillos, cada domingo el barrio lavapies cuenta con el mas castizo y grande de Madrid:  El Rastro, donde podras conseguir piezas que quizas no veas en otros lugares.

Neighborhood Overview: It can be said without hesitation that this flat enjoys the best location on offer for a holiday in Madrid. Practically a stone's throw away from Madrid's 3 most important art galleries (Prado, Thyssen and Reina Sofia), it straddles the historic Barrio de las Letras and the Huertas Neighbourhoods with their cultural offer and bustling nightlife, while being a 5 minute walk away from Madrid’s famous Retiro Park and 10 minutes from walk from the Puerta del Sol. The street itself is beautiful, lined with bars, restaurants and taverns but the flat is very quiet at night. All of central Madrid (Sol, Gran Via, Lavapies, Plaza Mayor) is within walking distance from the flat..

Neighborhood Overview: El apartamento está ubicado en un barrio muy seguro, céntrico y con ambientillo, además de tranquilo.En cualquier época del año hay gente por la calle o las terrazas, pero sin aglomeraciones.También circulan muchos taxis.      A pocos metros nos encontramos con terrazas todo el año.En calle Ponzano o calle Alvarez de Castro y plaza Olavide y sus alrededores tenemos un buen ejemplo de lugares donde hay mayor concentración de bares de tapeo y restaurantes, con gran variedad de estilos para gustos diferentes, desde lo mas típico hasta lo mas sofisticado.Todo ello bastante diferente  a la masificación turística de otras zonas céntricas.      De compras: El Corte Inglés de Castellana está a 15 o 20 minutos andando. Si buscamos algo mas alternativo y especial, la calle Fuencarral y su Mercado.Los museos del Prado y Reina Sofía a 20 minutos en transporte público.Además hay museos agradables de visitar a los que se puede ir dando un paseo, como el Sorolla.

Neighborhood Overview: Es un barrio de vecinos vivo, alegre, con tiendas pequeñas. Es un lugar tranquilo, sin fiestas nocturnas, confiable. Encuentras maravillosas panaderías, tiendas bio con productos ecológicos, pastelerías exquisitas, heladerías, y muy buenos espacios para cenar, comer y tomar un rico vino charlando. Puedes ir andando o en bici a cualquier punto del centro y, claro, disfrutar del footing en el Retiro, del sol sobre su hierba, de remar,de patinar, de los columpios o de los altos árboles :) Estamos a 10 min andando de la Milla de oro, aunque calles como Goya o Serrano ofrecen mucho más que Alta Costura: museos, bares y restaurantes chic...El Palacio de Deportes, y grandes hospitales como el Gregorio Marañón se encuentran a menos de 10 min andando.

Neighborhood Overview: Retiro is home to Madrid’s beloved Parque del Buen Retiro, where Madrileños gather, especially on sunny days, to spend time with their families, friends and beloved ones. While the area is very expensive, it is a location that is on high demand because of its bike and runnings paths, sports centers, and gardens that compete with those of New York's own Central Park. Neighborhood Overview: La vivienda está situada A 10 minutos a pie  de la estación del AVE de Atocha, en el corazón de Madrid. Muy cerca de los Museos del Prado, Reina Sofía y Thyssen-Bornemisza. En poco menos de 15 minutos podrá pasear por el Parque del Retiro o por el Jardín Botánico. Su privilegiada ubicación permite recorrer el centro de Madrid a pie y descansar en una zona libre de ruidos nocturnos. Probablemente uno de los mayores atractivos de este alojamiento sea la disposición de sus comunicaciones, por su cercanía a las estaciones de Metro de Atocha y Palos de la Frontera, a la de Tren de Atocha, sin olvidarnos de la infinidad de autobuses urbanos que disponen de paradas junto a la vivienda. En 45 minutos usando transporte público llegaremos al Aeropuerto “Adolfo Suarez” Madrid Barajas. La comunicación en vehículo propio también es comodísima, ya que en menos de 3 minutos podremos acceder a la M-30, la radial más importante de la ciudad de Madrid, que posibilita una rápida comunicación con cualquie

Neighborhood Overview: Callao is one of the most popular plazas in Madrid. It sits right on the edge of Madrid’s Theatre district, the very popular city centre Sol and beautiful Royal district of Opera. Plaza Callao is Madrids own version of Times Square with its tall buildings, busy streets and constant hustle and bustle. Not only is Callao great for it’s central location, it is a perfect spot for those interested in the theatre and cinema of Spain. All year round there are a wide variety of plays, musicals, movies and even special movie premiers. The neighborhood is a perfect mix between classic 1920’s and modern architecture – which makes it a great place to explore. And don’t forget about the shopping! The streets along Callao are some of the best in the city for clothing, shoes, makeup and technology. The flat is located in Calle Preciados and just 1 minute away from Plaza Callao. The area surrounding the building is a known spot for good restaurants and entertainment.

Neighborhood Overview: The location of this apartment is ideal for walking the city's most significant tourist and historical sites of Madrid. Beautiful places like the Plaza of Spain, the Plaza del Callao, Opera, Plaza Mayor, Puerta del Sol,... Stunning streets are only 1 minute: Gran Via and Calle de la Princesa, full of cinemas, theaters, shops and restaurants. Or the street Preciados with many prestigious shops, bars with terraces and lots of entertainment. Visit the main museums like El Prado, Thyssen and Reina Sofia and the Royal Palace. Another option is to take a bus that does tours of the city. Only 200 m. begins the Plaza of Spain, which is the gateway to the largest green area of Madrid. To his left are the 2 gardens of the Royal Palace: "Sabatini" and "Campo del Moro", and right there is the "Temple of Debod" and "West Park", where you can take the cable car from which is a view of Madrid from above, through the "Casa de Campo" .

Neighborhood Overview: La Latina is one of the oldest neighborhoods in Madrid and is famous for its large number of tapas bars and restaurants, charming small streets with colorful facades, nightlife, and numerous small antique shops. Calle de Cava Baja and Cava Alta are the most famous streets for tapas, bars, and traditional Spanish "tabernas," or taverns, as well as Plaza de la Cebada and Plaza de la Paja, all of which are only a few minutes walking away. Every Sunday, rain or shine, La Latina hosts "El Rastro," which is one of the biggest flea markets in all of Europe. The main street for El Rastro is Calle de la Ribera de Curtidores, but it extends into many little side-streets as well. In general, weekends in La Latina are very lively, full of people mingling and walking around or having a drink in one of the sunny restaurant terraces.  You can also enjoy a typical Spanish food market, Mercado de la Cebada, right next to the La Latina metro stop, which is open Monday to Friday from 9AM-2PM and 5PM-8PM,
Street: La Latina, Madrid, Comunidad de Madrid 28005, Spain

Neighborhood Overview: The apartment is located in a unique setting in the historic center of Madrid. It is situated in an area called “La Latina”, where there are various entertainment and leisure spaces such as restaurants, cafes, bars, theaters ... It is just 5-10 minutes away (walking distance) from the Plaza Mayor, Puerta del Sol, Catedral de la Almudena, San Francisco el Grande, Palacio Real, Plaza de Oriente, Calle Preciados, Gran Vía… In addition, it is one of the most iconic, pure and authentic neighborhoods of Madrid. You will find the famous outdoor market "El Rastro" (Sunday mornings and holidays) just 100 meters away. Neighborhood Overview: The Latina is one of the city's most atmospheric neighbourhoods in the centre of Madrid. There are quite a few nightlife spots, though the area is best known as having the best concentrations of tapas bars. Sometimes referred to as El Madrid de los Austrias, La Latina occupies the oldest area in Madrid, the Islamic citadel inside the city walls, which maintains a peculiar urban layout similar to the medieval distribution with narrow streets and large squares.   In a walking distance to the apartment there are the most of the spots of interests and main attractions. The Palacio Real (Royal Palace), Plaza Mayor,  Puerta del  sol, Gran via, barrio de las letras.  On Sundays and major holidays, the Rastro a street-market is well known and visited. The Plaza of la Cebada has functioned as a food market and Plaza de la Paja is another interesting and entertaining spot of this neighbourhood.
Street: La Latina, Madrid, Madrid 28005, Spain

Neighborhood Overview: La calle Narváez, que tiene su inicio en la confluencia de Goya y Alcalá, atraviesa el barrio de Ibiza y corre paralela al lado este del parque de El Retiro. Por su proximidad al gran pulmón de Madrid, ésta es una zona habitual de paseo, muy frecuentada a la hora de tomar el aperitivo, por lo que cuenta con un importante tejido comercial. Artesanía para el paladar Cada vez son más las tiendas de productos delicatessen –cervezas artesanales en Birra y Paz, en la calle Menorca– o restaurantes de cocina de vanguardia, así como pastelerías cuyas últimas generaciones de profesionales han virado hacia la creación gourmet. A caballo entre esa tradición y novedad están establecimientos como Nunos –calle Narváez 63–, referencia en la elaboración de buñuelos y torrijas, con colecciones temáticas que sorprenden cada año. Y entre las tradicionales, la horchatería Alboraya –calle Felipe II–, para probar el auténtico refresco a base de chufas, tan típico de la costa del Levante español, o la helader

Neighborhood Overview: El Barrio de las Letras is named in tribute to the great writers who inhabited the streets in the Golden Age. Cervantes, Quevedo or Lope de Vega passed through this area between the Paseo del Prado and Plaza Santa Ana -one of the most popular squares of Madrid- by the charm of its pedestrian streets and many shops and restaurants that make it particularly lively on weekends. From the Plaza de Santa Ana, famous for its terraces and tapas bars, to the Paseo del Prado and famous streets such as Huertas, whose cobblestones carry engraved quotations from great writers in Castilian. Indeed, in the Lope de Vega Street, in the church of San Ildefonso (Convent of the Barefoot Trinitarians), a plaque recalls that in an unspecified location in the building the remains the body of the author of The Ingenious Hidalgo Don Quixote, Miguel de Cervantes. Neighborhood Overview: El barrio El Barrio de las Letras lleva su nombre en homenaje a los grandes literatos que habitaron sus calles en el Siglo de Oro. Cervantes, Quevedo o Lope de Vega transitaron por esta zona situada entre el paseo del Prado y la plaza de Santa Ana, una de las más populares de Madrid por el encanto de sus calles peatonales y sus muchas tiendas y restaurantes que la hacen especialmente animada los fines de semana. Desde la Plaza de Santa Ana, famosa por sus terrazas y bares de tapas, discurren en pendiente hasta el Paseo del Prado calles como la de Huertas, cuyos adoquines llevan grabadas citas de grandes escritores en castellano. Precisamente en la calle Lope de Vega, en la iglesia de San Ildefonso (convento de las Trinitarias Descalzas), una placa conmemorativa recuerda que en un lugar indeterminado del edificio descansan los restos del autor de El Ingenioso Hidalgo Don Quijote de la Mancha, Miguel de Cervantes. Neighborhood Overview: The neighborhood of La Latina is the oldest and most charismatic of Madrid. Its streets retain the layout already had for centuries, as seen in the plane of the Villa of 1656, and some of their names (door Moros, Plaza de la Cebada, street Morería, self-America) move us to a time when this area was the true center of life in the city. For locals this space formed between Calle Segovia, Vistillas, Puerta de Toledo, the Rastro and the Plaza de la Cebada not called otherwise than La Latina, and so is also reflected in the map of tourist areas published by the consistory itself. The name comes from Dona Beatriz Galindo, humanist and preceptor of the family of the Catholic Monarchs, who was known as America for being her teacher Latin, and whom the hospital foundation of America on the site should be where today find the Teatro La Latina.

Neighborhood Overview: This apartment is right in the centre of Madrid, between the neighbourhoods of Los Austrias and La Latina, in the oldest and loveliest part of the city. It has an unbeatable location in Plaza de Cascorro off Calle Duque de Alba, a few metres from Mercado de la Cebada, Calle Toledo and Plaza Mayor. El Rastro, a traditional open-air market, is held on Sundays in the area around the apartment, when the streets are closed to traffic until midday. La Latina is a must-see neighbourhood in Madrid. It is one of the most authentic places in the city, with lots of bars, tapas restaurants and sites of artistic interest. Strolling along its narrow streets is a delight. It is within easy walking distance of Museo del Prado, Museo Thyssen and Jardín Botánico.

Neighborhood Overview: El barrio de La Latina es un área de Madrid (España), administrativamente enclavada casi en su totalidad dentro del barrio de Palacio en el distrito de Centro. Neighborhood Overview: La Latina occupies much of the oldest section of Madrid, sometimes referred to as Madrid de los Austrias which maintains a peculiar urban layout similar to the medieval distribution, with spacious squares and narrow streets that follow the former course of creeks.  Its streets have felt the presence of all historical events that took place in Madrid in all periods, without losing its popular character. In this sense it can be said that La Latina constitutes a large part of the true historic center of Madrid.

Neighborhood Overview: It's on Retiro district, on Pacífico ward. Its name comes from the huge and beautiful public park called El Parque del Buen Retiro, nicknamed “El Retiro” by all madridians. This is how I would describe in a few words Retiro: – Green / Close to an amazing park – Posh – traditional – Close to the center. Life in the Retiro neighborhood is traditional, laid-back and still connected to the center. I really recommend to anyone who wants to enjoy Madrid, be right in the middle of things, live in an middle/upper-class neighborhood without pretensions, and still be able to escape from the city stress by going to the park anytime they want.  I recommend living in “Retiro” if you: – want to be connected to the center of Madrid, but in a quiet neighborhood, with an amazing park just 5 minutes from your place. – live in a really authentic Madrid neighborhood, where many people still live the Madrid way of life as it was years ago.
Street: Pacifico, Madrid, Comunidad de Madrid 28007, Spain

Neighborhood Overview: Estáis en una de las calles más de moda de Madrid. Encontraréis una combinación de modernidad y tradición, juventud y experiencia... En la calle Conde Duque, podréis comprar pan artesano en PANIC, tomar un sandwich de autor en CRUMB o probar quesos de todo el mundo en QUESERÍA CONDE DUQUE. Si queréis comprar ropa exclusiva, no olvidéis SPORTIVO, MINI, POLAR... Descansad y tomad un café y una tarta de zanahoria en EL JARDÍN SECRETO o en MÜR... Y todo esto sin salir de vuestra calle! Ahora os queda todo el barrio de MALASAÑA por explorar, podéis dar un pequeño paseo hasta CHUECA y seguir descubriendo una sorpresa en cada esquina. ¡Que disfrutéis!

Neighborhood Overview: Only a 3-minute walk from both Gran Vía Avenue and Puerta del Sol, the New Point Madrid has self-catering accommodations in the center of Madrid. It features a terrace and free Wi-Fi. All air-conditioned apartments have a modern décor, hardwood floors and a sitting area. Some of the rooms include a flat-screen TV, a balcony and a patio. All have a full kitchen with a fridge, a dining area and a washing machine. Featuring a shower, the private bathrooms also have a hairdryer. Towels and sheets are included. At the New Point Madrid, guests will find a tour desk. Extras include ironing facilities and guests can use the apartment land-line phone free of charge. Madrid’s famous Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum is just a 10-minute walk from New Point Madrid and a 5-mimute walk to the lively Chueca district, famous for its café bars and restaurants. If we were not from Madrid we would like someone recommends to us these sites, but it's all about taste ... TAPAS La Perejila (Calle Cava Baja, 25) Tapas from Southern Spain with traditional "copla" music and good ambient La taberna del Almendro 13 (Calle Almendro 13) Authentic from Madrid, even if you find some tourists there Arbonaida (Calle Santiago, 11) Tapas from Andalucía by a great chef, fresh smoothies and good ambient.  Taberna de La Dolores (Plaza de Jesús, 4) Best cañas in Madrid. Nothing more to say HOMEMADE SPANISH FOOD Viuda de vacas (Calle Águila, 23) It is amazing to try real food from Madrid, the most "castizo" you will find. Try “Potaje de garbanzos con espinacas”, “callos a la madrileña”, “gallina en pepitoria”, “jamón asado” y “lomo alto” and boletus when season. Casa Perico (Calle Ballesta, 18)  Across Gran Vía you

Neighborhood Overview: Downtown Las Letras district. This elegant neighborhood is the heart of the traditional, cultural and new chic Madrid. The area is a mixture of quiet and charming pedestrian streets. Very safe and protected, it is an oasis of peace restricted only to the residents’ cars.  The most important museums in Madrid, such as the PRADO, Thyssen or Reina Sofia, are 2 minutes’ walk. Very close to the beautiful and lively Plaza de Santa Ana -5 minutes’ walk-, full of sunny terraces, cafes and most typical TAPAS bars of the city. In the surrounding streets, such as Huertas, you may find exclusive Jazz, Blues or Soul Live Cafes, highlighting the internationally known Café Central or Populart. And of course! Flamenco! There is plenty of “tablaos” in the area, for example, the legendary Villa Rosa. And you can taste the most varied and delicious Spanish cuisine in the typical old taverns and restaurants, such as Casa Alberto, Taberna La Dolores, Los Gatos, Bar Quevedo and others. Neighborhood Overview: El Barrio de las Letras es un céntrico barrio de la ciudad de Madrid en el que han vivido y escrito algunos de los grandes literatos de España. Hoy es un área que combina literatura, bohemia, diversión, compras y buena gastronomía. El barrio está formado por pequeñas calles, peatonales o de acceso restringido a vehículos, y agradables plazas como la de Santa Ana. En ellas, es fácil encontrar casas en las que vivieron y escribieron figuras tan importantes de la literatura del Siglo de Oro de España como Lope de Vega, Quevedo, Góngora o Cervantes. Asimismo, en el pavimento de diversas calles se encuentran inscripciones y pequeños textos de la obra de algunos de ellos. Otro de los encantos del “Barrio de las Letras” es su amplia oferta comercial, que va desde los más tradicionales establecimientos con siglos de historia (como zapateros, plateros o lutieres) a espacios modernos y vanguardistas. Neighborhood Overview: Situado en la zona Triball. Triball fue creado con el apoyo del Ayuntamiento de Madrid con el fin de desarrollar y promover el vecindario . Pudiendo encontrar tiendas antiguas y de vanguardia. Está a pocos pasos de la Plaza de Callao y Gran Vía, a tan sólo 5 minutos,  y de Puerta del Sol a 10 minutos Está a 2 minutos andando del Teatro Lara. En el vecindario podrá encontrar numerosos bares, restaurantes con terrazas donde degustar deliciosas tapas . Si decide ir un día de compras, encontrará tiendas de moda con un gusto exquisito. Hay muchas tiendas vintage en el barrio. Es una zona muy animada con muchas posibilidades de ocio, vida nocturna y diurna.  Debido a su excelente ubicación, pueden ir caminando a los principales museos El Prado, Thyssen... Justo al lado de casa, en la misma acera, a menos de 20 metros, se pueden encontrar varios supermercados.

A un paso del antiguo barrio judío Lavapiés el cual es famoso por sus numerosos bares de tapas, su ambiente y oferta multicultural,  y su fiesta popular de San Cayetano en el mes de Agosto. Atravesando este barrio llegaremos a Plaza sol en 15 minutos a pie. Otras zonas cercanas para salir de fiesta son Huertas , chueca y la Latina. Varios supermercados ,tiendas de frutas y verduras y todos los servicios de barrio a escasos minutos. Neighborhood Overview: La Latina is one of the most authentic neighborhoods of Madrid. It is known as "el barrio de los Austrias" and its characteristic buildings have a multitude of Renaissance style balconies and windows. It is located in the heart of Madrid and embraces the streets that descend from the Plaza Mayor to the Gardens of Las Vistillas, where the famous patron saint of Madrid is celebrated: San Isidro. La Latina is also the heart of the "movida madrileña" and in its small winding streets you can find the ideal place to have a coffee, sip a good wine or enjoy the best dinner in Madrid, and get involved in its vibrant nightlife without changing neighborhood.

Neighborhood Overview: The area immediately surrounding the apartment is bursting with history and culture, with a number of sights of interest nearby. These include the beautiful Royal Palace and Sabatini gardens, the Almudena cathedral, and the lovely Campo del Moro, one of the most charming parks in the city. The neighbourhood is known for both its excellent traditional tabernas and its modern bars and restaurants, and is popular with both visitors and residents alike looking for a great meal and evening out. A little further afield but still within easy walking distance are a number of the capital’s top sights and attractions, including the Plaza de Espana, art deco Gran Via avenue, the Templo de Debod park, and the Puerta del Sol, the very centre of Madrid.

Neighborhood Overview: Chueca is in the neighborhood of "Justicia", located in centre district of the city of Madrid, Spain. It is located in the heart of Madrid, next to Gran Via and Fuencarral streets and between Barquillo Street. In the 90s it became definitely gay neighborhood of Madrid, having been progressively chosen as place for recreation and residence of most of Madrid's gay community since the 80s. The neighborhood has a lively and modern character, very open and respectful of the diversity of modern society. It has a very commercial and recreational environment without losing its castizo air because of its architecture. In its streets, in addition to traditional stores, people may find restaurants, bars, fashion boutiques, etc. All this among its renovated buildings with colorful facades. This is a highly recommended neighborhood for walking while discovering its corners, and from where you the main sights of the city can be reached in a few minutes.
